> The real problem though is that Java is not designed to work this way.
> Interfaces are not meant to replace classes. In particular, the lack
> of method preconditions and postconditions means that you can no
> longer make any promises about what a given method accepts or returns
> beyond the simple return type. The reason we have access protection
> as a language feature is because we cannot rely on programmer
> convention to enforce rules. Using interfaces instead of classes
> reduces us to using programmer convention to enforce constraints that
> should be enforced in code.

Sorry, I don't understand this. How do you enforce the constraints in code?

Curious, Ilja
